Study: Relationship between Average Daily Temperature and Average Cumulative Daily Rate of Confirmed Cases of COVID-19
Effect: We found that when there is a significant difference in the daily mean temperature between two regions of a country, a significant difference exists also in the average cumulative daily rate of confirmed cases.

Study: Correlation between weather and Covid-19 pandemic in Jakarta, Indonesia
Factors Described: temperature minimum (°C), temperature maximum (°C), temperature average (°C), humidity (%), and amount of Rainfall (mm).
Effect: only temperature average (°C) was significantly correlated with covid-19 pandemic (r = 0.392; p < .01).

Study: Meteorological factors correlate with transmission of 2019-nCoV: Proof of incidence of novel coronavirus pneumonia in Hubei Province, China
Significant Factors: Average pressure, Average temperature, Minimum temperature, Average water vapor pressure
Factors Described: Average Temperature, Maximum Temperature, Minimum Temperature, Average Pressure, Average water temperature pressure, Average Relative Humidity, Average Windspeed, Precipitation, Total solar radiation, Maximum Solar Irradiance
Effect: the incidence of COVID-19 was significantly positively correlated with average pressure and negatively correlated with average temperature, minimum temperature and average water vapor pressure

Study: Temperature, humidity, and wind speed are associated with lower Covid-19 incidence
Effect: Cold and dry environments are more favourable condition for virus survival

Study: No Evidence for Temperature-Dependence of the COVID-19 Epidemic
Effect: no evidence that spread rates decline with temperatures above 20 oC
Measure of Evidence: Data from WHO, ECDC, and John Hopkin CSSA on all affected countries

Study: COVID-19 transmission in Mainland China is associated with temperature and humidity: a time-series analysis
Effect: Every 1C increase in the AT led to a decrease in the daily confirmed cases by 36% to 57% when ARH was in the range from 67% to 85.5%. Every 1% increase in ARH led to a decrease in the daily confirmed cases by 11% to 22% when AT was in the range from 5.04°C to 8.2°C. However, results were not consistent throughout provinces in mainland china

Study: Effects of temperature on COVID-19 transmission
Effect: Changes in temperature shows no significant correlation with cases transmitted, deaths or recovered:

Study: Effects of temperature variation and humidity on the death of COVID-19 in Wuhan, China
Factors Described: Temperature, Diurnal Temperature Range, Relative Humidity, Air Pollutant
Effect: Both per 1 unit increase of temperature and absolute humidity were related to the decreased COVID-19 death counts

Study: Causal empirical estimates suggest COVID-19 transmission rates are highly seasonal
Effect: 1C increase in local temperature reduces new COVID-19 cases per 1 million people by 13%, with a 95% confidence interval of [-21%, -4%]

Study: The impact of temperature and absolute humidity on the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak - evidence from China
Effect: Transmission rate decreased with the increase of temperature

Study: Association between ambient temperature and COVID-19 infection in 122 cities from China
Effect: Our results indicate that mean temperature has a positive linear relationship with the number of COVID-19 cases with a threshold of 3 °C.

Study: Roles of meteorological conditions in COVID-19 transmission on a worldwide scale
Factors Described: Air Temperature, Relative Humidity, Wind Speed, Visibility
Effect: Multiple environmental factors are involved

Study: Effects of temperature variation and humidity on the mortality of COVID-19 in Wuhan
Factors Described: Temperature, Diurnal Temperature Range, Relative Humidity, Air Pollutant
Effect: Each 1 unit increase in diurnal temperature range was only associated with a 2.92% (95% CI: 0.61%, 5.28%) increase in COVID-19 mortality at lag 3

Study: Role of temperature and humidity in the modulation of the doubling time of COVID-19 cases
Effect: Results indicate that the doubling time correlates positively with temperature and inversely with humidity. A 20C increase is expected to delay the doubling time in 1.8 days.

Study: Projecting the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 through the post-pandemic period
Effect: SARS-CoV- 2 was capable of producing a substantial outbreak regardless of establishment time. Winter/spring establishments favored longer-lasting outbreaks with shorter peaks (Fig 3A), while autumn/winter establishments led to more acute outbreaks

Study: Potential Factors Influencing Repeated SARS Outbreaks in China.
Effect: A cold, dry environment is more conducive for SARS-COV-2 viral infection in human beings

Study: The Effects of "Fangcang Huoshenshan and Leishenshan" Makeshift Hospitals and Temperature on the Mortality of COVID-19
Effect: if the AT rises 1 Celsius, the mortality of confirmed cases would decrease 0.44% and the mortality of severe cases would decrease 0.42% on average.

Study: Molecular mechanism of evolution and human infection with the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)
Effect: 2019-nCoV will be less infectious with rising temperature and more infectious in the Winter

Study: Analysis of meteorological conditions and prediction of epidemic trend of 2019-nCoV infection in 2020
Effect: The humidity range is 50%-80%, of which about 75% humidity is conducive to the survival of the coronavirus; the suitable precipitation range is below 30 mm/ month. Cities with a mean temperature below 24 °C are all high-risk cities for 2019-nCoV
Measure of Evidence: Data from Patients in Wuhan and Guangzhou

Study: The role of absolute humidity on transmission rates of the COVID-19 outbreak
Effect: Weather alone will not lead to a decrease in COVID 19 Cases
Measure of Evidence: Data from WHO, U.S. CDC, CDC, European CDC, the Chinese NHC, DXY (Chinese website that aggregates NHC and local CCDC situation reports) in near real-time. For comparison, we also obtained epidemiological data for affected countries including Thailand, Singapore, Japan, and South Korea, as well as other regions in China with important differences in data collection,
